posts.name: A Family in the Northeast
posts.note: From Titus Ruscitti's website about A Family in the Northeast, 'Speaking of the Richland Center basement, there's a new stall selling open-ended potstickers called “A family in the Northeast.” This stall has hosted a few places over the years, with this newest tenant specializing in open-ended potstickers, bing, and bao. They offer a handful of fillings, and the traditional pork and leek were pretty good. Some people aren't fans of the open-ended wrap because of the juices from inside that they can lose. That said, these were still pretty juicy but suffered slightly from a packaged trip from the mall to my car. They steamed a bit and lost some of that would be a crunch.'

posts.name: Al's Italian Beef
posts.note: Al’s Italian Beef is a Chicago-based chain known for overstuffed Italian beef sandwiches and hot dogs in a bare-bones space. From their website, ‘The purported origins of the Italian beef sandwich can be traced back to this Taylor Street stand in Little Italy. That’s where Al Ferrari and his sister and brother-in-law, Frances and Chris Pacelli Sr., set up shop in 1938 and started popularizing what would become one of the city’s iconic foods. Today, the original location is still in business, and the beef remains unchanged — marinated in secret spices and dipped in gravy. So stop in, assume the proper upright eating stance, and savor a bit of Chicago history.’ NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Athenian Room
posts.note: Athenian Room is a casual restaurant cooking Greek specialties like gyros and juice-soaked fries since the 1970s. Tina Fey recommended the Kalamata chicken dinner, which is a half chicken over steak fries with lemon herb sauce that soaks in with the chicken fat to the fries. From their website ‘Lincoln Park’s Greek eatery has been a neighborhood staple for more than four decades, thanks in large part to its popular roast chicken. In fact, Tiny Fey loves the dish so much she called the restaurant one of her favorite places to eat in town. And when it comes to food, we won’t argue with Liz Lemon.’
posts.rcmmnd: Tina Fey on David Letterman show “My Next Guest Needs No Introduction”

posts.name: Bang Bang Pie and Biscuits
posts.note: Bang Bang Pie and Biscuits is a rustic bakery with a rotating menu of homemade sweet and savory pies and biscuits for eat-in or takeout. Phil from the show Somebody Feed Phil (Netflix) recommends the candied bacon and the BLT Biscuit, or the sorghum butter, and for dessert, the peach pie with corneal crumble or the malted milk chocolate with whip cream or the pistachio and blueberry compote or peanut butter custard with raspberry preserves and toasted peanuts. From their website, ‘Bang Bang Pie and Biscuits continues Mid-Western cooking traditions, eager to serve up our unique take on hospitality, decadence and cafe life.’ From the Chicago Eater website, ‘Though it’s best known for its sweet pies, Bang Bang Pie also sells savory pies and quiches. The menu varies depending on the season, but there’s usually a classic chicken pot pie and a vegetarian Southern tomato, filled with spicy tomatoes and cheddar cheese. All pies are available whole or by the slice.’

posts.name: Big Delicious Planet - Catering, Canteen, and Urban Farm
posts.note: Big Delicious Planet - Catering, Canteen, and Urban Farm is an inviting cafe connected to a catering operation offering coffee, pastries, and eco-focused meals. They have their own urban farm nearby. Its owner is Heidi Moorman Coudal. Yes, it’s that Coudal. From their website, ‘Since our founding in 1994, Big Delicious Planet has evolved from catering backstage for thousands of the world’s most popular artists to a certified green farm-to-table operation with a busy cafe and a lush urban farm. Throughout BDP’s history, our passion has been creating unforgettable experiences for our clients, whether it’s catering a stylish wedding, designing a one-of-a-kind event in the middle of our own urban farm, or feeding globally-inspired cuisine to employees of the world’s most recognized brands. Delicious, high-quality food and eye-catching presentations have remained the focus of our catering from day one.’

posts.name: Billy Goat Tavern
posts.note: The Billy Goat Tavern is a Chicago legend since 1934 associated with the Cubs curse and Saturday Night Live. 'Cheezeborger, cheezeborger' and more in an underground haunt made famous by a recurring SNL skit. From the USA Today website, ‘For those of a certain age, the Billy Goat Tavern is best known as its fictional incarnation, Olympia Tavern, the setting for a famed recurring Saturday Night Live skit in the John Belushi and Bill Murray era. The Olympia was a three-item Greek café where the only options were “cheeburger,” chips, and Pepsi, as in the famous gag line, “No Coke! Pepsi!” Both Belushi and Murray were veterans of Chicago’s famed Second City comedy troupe and were familiar with the real-life Billy Goat Tavern, on which the skit was based.’ NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Birrieria Zaragoza
posts.note: From the Chicago Eater website, ‘The Zaragoza clan has been dishing up the celebratory Jalisco dish for almost more than 15  years, sticking to a 100-year-old heirloom recipe from the Los Altos region. The family, featured on Netflix’s Taco Chronicles along with three other Chicago favorites, takes great pride in their process and ingredients, which include raising their goats. The meat is seasoned and cooked for several hours and served with a tomato consommé, red mole,  handmade tortillas, and a fleet of garnishes (onions, cilantro, chilis,  and lime). Try your birria or head taco with the molcajete sauce made with fire-roasted tomatoes and chilis — it is the G.O.A.T. Way before the birria boom driven by social media hit our feeds, the Zaragoza family had already been serving the festive Jalisco stew for nearly 15  years. And while there are many ways to enjoy birria, the Zaragozas stick to a 100-year-old heirloom recipe from the Los Altos de Jalisco region. The family, recently featured on Netflix’s Taco Chronicles,  takes great pride in their process and ingredients, which include raising their goats. The meat is seasoned and cooked for several hours and served with a tomato consommé, red mole, handmade tortillas, and a fleet of garnishes (onions, cilantro, chilis, and lime). Follow the juicy and tender birria with a goat head taco. It is crispy, lightly brushed with an ancho-based mole, and finished on a comal. The molcajete sauce made with fire-roasted tomatoes and chilis is not to be missed.’ Recommend ordering crispy cabeza de chivo taco.

posts.name: Bob Chinn's Crab House
posts.note: Bob Chinn’s has been an institution since 1982 in Wheeling, IL. For over 35 years, they have served some of the Freshest Seafood from around the globe- Alaska, Hawaii, New Zealand - to name a few. Specializing in seafood, they’re also known for our wet-aged prime steaks that are comparable to some of the best steakhouses. Starting off as a restaurant that only seated 200, expanded to over 700 seats in five years. Come inside and judge for yourself on the quality and freshness of the finest food you will ever taste, served by their friendly and enthusiastic staff. From the Chicago Eater website ‘In the northern suburbs, Bob Chinn’s is synonymous with seafood. The sprawling crab shack has been serving fresh seafood since 1982, much of it flown in from the Atlantic and Pacific and prepared in a variety of ways. But the house specialty remains crab legs, preferably served with a basket or two of the famous garlic rolls.’

posts.name: Chicago French Market
posts.note: Chicago French Market is a European-inspired indoor food market for grab-and-go meals, fresh produce, and specialty kiosks. From their website, 'As the Original Chicago Food Hall, Chicago French Market is fast becoming a destination for tourists and locals alike. The in-house seating area is reminiscent of a Parisian street cafe. Photo-ops in the seating area are frequent, with an original art mural of Paris at night as a backdrop. We encourage you to come in and enjoy this truly unique space. The Chicago French Market also offers fresh ingredients for cooking at home, delicious grab-and-go options for breakfast, lunch, and dinner, light snacks, picnics, easy party planning for home and office settings, plus meaningful gift ideas, all in one convenient location.'

posts.name: Cindy's Rooftop
posts.note: Cindy's Rooftop is a hip, stylish rooftop bar/eatery at the Chicago Athletic Association Hotel with choice seasonal fare. Phil from the Somebody Feed Phil (Netflix) show recommends going there for drinks. From their website, 'The Jewel in the Crown Of The Chicago Athletic Association Hotel, Cindy's Rooftop Restaurant and open-air terrace offers panoramic views of Millennium Park, sparkling Lake Michigan, The Art Institute Of Chicago, and beyond. Join Executive Chef Christian Ragano and his team for seasonally-rotating, family-style comfort food, bio-dynamic wines, and award-winning cocktails with large format apothecaries. With seasonal freshness reflected in food and drink, this Chicago restaurant serves locally-sourced, New American cuisine within the relaxed ambiance of a Great Lakes beach house.'

posts.name: Dangela's Dumplings
posts.note: Dangela's Dumplings is a relaxed spot offering pan-seared and boiled Chinese dumplings with various fillings along with pots of tea. From their website, 'We're proud to feature our specialty dumplings prepared just the way you like. Our dumplings are created from scratch, using the freshest ingredients and traditional Chinese recipes to ensure every bite is absolutely scrumptious. The tasty ingredients in our dumplings include pork, beef, onion, egg, shrimp, zucchini, and more. You'll also want to try our tantalizing side dishes, which include steamed broccoli, shredded potato, cabbage, and seaweed salad, among others.' From Titus Ruscitti's website, 'As the name suggests, this is a dumpling house. Meaning that's pretty much all they do. Dangela being a middle-aged Chinese lady who lives in the area and opened this spiffy clean ready for franchising restaurant towards the end of 2019. They offer a handful of fillings that tell you the “exact“ portioning of each filler (ex. Pork and Celery - 80% Pork, 20% Celery). We tried the shrimp (45%), Sweet Corn (40%), and Chinese Chives (15%) in boiled form, and they were legit. I liked the fried pork and celery version even more as she ordered a couple machines from Asia specifically made for cooking dumplings. They're rectangular in shape, so you can put in ten dumplings per machine.'

posts.name: La Autentica De Guerrero
posts.note: From the La Autentica De Guerrero website, 'La Autentica De Guerrero, in Chicago, IL, is the leading Mexican restaurant serving Chicago, Joliet, Aurora, Elmwood Park, and surrounding areas since 2020. We offer delicious Mexican cuisine including tacos, burritos, menudo, picaditas, tamales, barbacoa, and much more. For your next meal, visit La Autentica De Guerrero in Chicago.' Titus tweeted 'Gordita with Barbacoa de Res estilo Guerrero La Autentica De Guerrero (Belmont Cragin)' translated from Spanish 'Gordita with Warrior Style Beef Barbecue The Authentic Warrior (Belmont Cragin)'

posts.name: Del Seoul
posts.note: Del Seoul is a no-frills counter-service eatery with Asian fusion eats like Korean BBQ tacos and banh mi sandwiches. You need to order lollipop K-town Chicken Wings or Kalbi (braised short rib) poutine or the Veggie Bibimbop. From their website, 'Our inspiration comes from the Korean “street foods” of California, Asia, and Korea. Our goal is simple: to put a modern, unique spin on Korean food. We’re also a family-owned business. We honor tradition but also love trying new things. We believe in keeping things fresh and unique. We believe in popular, not trendy. We believe that customer-focused and food-focused is the only way to go.'

posts.name: Do-Rite Donuts and Chicken
posts.note: From their website, ‘Chef-owned counter for artisanal donuts in unusual flavors, along with fried chicken sandwiches and coffee.’ From the Chicago Eater website, ‘Whether it’s pistachio-Meyer lemon or buttermilk old fashions, Do-Rite’s got it on the menu. As a bonus, the shop carries gluten-free and vegan options as well. There are seven locations in the city and suburbs.’ NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Doughnut Vault
posts.note: Doughnut Vault is a tiny bakery selling a handful of donut choices each day until the stock runs out. Owner Brendan Sodikoff started selling big, fresh doughnuts out of a brick storefront in the spring of 2011, and lines continue from early morning until the handful of flavors sell out. Outside, there's a communal table for enjoying old-fashioned, chocolate-glazed doughnuts and salted peanuts, with cheap cups of coffee. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Hogsalt Hospitality’s sweets spot is among the most popular in the city. Creative specials, such as dulce de leche and honey bun cake, are offered daily alongside favorites like the old-fashioned. Arrive early because there’s usually a line, and once everything is sold out, Doughnut Vault closes for the day. There are three locations.'ss

posts.name: Dove's Luncheonette
posts.note: Dove's Luncheonette is a Tex-Mex diner eats plus cocktails and lots of tequila in retro digs with counter seats and a jukebox. The burnt ends hash I saw on TV look like the thing to order when you're there. From the Chicago Eater website, 'This charming Tex-Mex diner from One Off Hospitality (Publican, Big Star) has become a popular standby for Wicker Park residents with a hankering for breakfast and brunch indulgences like burnt ends hash and chicken fried chicken.'

posts.name: Duck Duck Goat
posts.note: Duck Duck Goat is a creative Chinese fare from celeb chef Stephanie Izard served in buzzy, ornately decorated surrounds. From the Chicago Eater website, ‘Chef Stephanie Izard’s tribute to Chinatowns around the world is one of the most beautiful restaurants in Chicago, and the menu contains all the usual suspects: dim sum, mapo tofu, and a seasonal special Peking duck.’

posts.name: Elske
posts.note: Elske is a low-key spot offering à la carte and tasting menus of creative American fare with Danish influences. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Last December, pedigreed chefs David and Anna Posey (Blackbird, Alinea, Trio) opened their very first restaurant, Elske. Sporting a stylish array of locally sourced, hyper-seasonal ingredients, the spot had one notable lofty ambition: to change the tasting menu game in Chicago by offering a multi-course experience that was simultaneously affordable and laid back. “We were inspired by the modern-style bistros of Paris and throughout Europe — how you could go to Le Chateaubriand and have very forward-thinking food for about $60,” says David. “We just want [customers to get] interesting food that [they] can’t make at home.”'

posts.name: Four Seasons Dumplings
posts.note: From Titus Ruscitti's website about Four Seasons Dumplings, 'The city's newest dumpling shop sits on Halsted in Bridgeport across from the police station parking lot. They also specialize in house-made lo mein, which is pretty good if you like subtle flavors paired with chewy noodles (try the green bean version). But don't miss out on the dumplings, which potsticker-wise are probably my favorite in town right now. I haven't tried the steamed options because I think those would be much better dining in, but the style of fried dumplings they do here aren't the type to get all stuck together when taken to go.' From their website, 'Four Seasons Dumpling is a cornerstone in the Chicago community and has been recognized for its outstanding Chinese cuisine, excellent service, and friendly staff. Our Chinese restaurant is known for its modern interpretation of classic dishes and its insistence on only using high-quality fresh ingredients.'

posts.name: Firecakes Donuts
posts.note: From their website, ‘Our small-batch donuts are baked from scratch daily in one of our Chicago-land bakeries. Our bakers begin the process in the wee hours and continue throughout the morning.’ From the Chicago Eater website, ‘Firecakes has four locations in the city and the suburbs, and they’ll all be carrying the seasonal hot chocolate doughnut, a classic cake covered in a layer of fudge with a pink peppermint marshmallow covering up the hole. This popular local mini-chain has returned with its annual smattering of sufganiyot, available with raspberry-blood orange jelly or lemon curd filling.’

posts.name: Fullerton Restaurant
posts.note: Fullerton Restaurant is a down-to-earth diner supplying breakfast, burgers, and other familiar American standards. Titus Ruscitti recommends the Akutagawa, which is a little known regional dish that came out of Chicago’s Japanese-American community, which thrived in Lakeview post World War II. It’s wok scrambled eggs that are stir-fried with green pepper, onion, and bean sprouts with your choice of meat with chopped hamburger being standard along with a side of rice and gravy, plus toast.

posts.name: The Game Room
posts.note: The Game Room in the Chicago Athletic Association Hotel is a retro-chic lounge offering classic cocktails and finger foods, along with bocce, pool, cards, and foosball. From their website, 'Game Room is exactly that — a sprawling space on the second floor of the Chicago Athletic Association packed with shuffleboard, foosball, bocce, billiards, checkers, chess, and more. Accompanying the games is a playful menu of creative takes on street food favorites, including burgers, fried pickle pops, falafel, fried chicken sandwiches, chicken wings, and more. The drink menu includes an accessible selection of classic cocktails, including rotating seasonal variations on Cobblers, Collins, Old Fashioneds, Sours, and more. Game Room also offers a range of craft beers, including limited-edition collaborations with local breweries, and a curated wine list.'

posts.name: Girl and the Goat
posts.note: Girl and the Goat is the hot spot where Stephanie Izard serves up innovative small plates from a dramatic open kitchen. The Girl and the Goat opened with the goal of serving a family-style menu of tasty, bold flavored foods with global influences in a fun and lively setting that makes their guests feel at home from the moment they walk in the door. From their website, ‘As one of the first restaurants on Chicago’s famed Restaurant Row in the West Loop, Stephanie Izard’s Girl & the Goat began in 2010 with a goal of serving bold, global flavors to our local community (and visitors!). Since then, our desire to treat guests like family has remained the same (as have our Green Beans) – but our seasonal flavors, cocktails, wine, and locally-rooted beer are ever-changing.’

posts.name: Hing Kee
posts.note: Hing Kee serves hand-drawn noodle soup is a feature at this welcoming restaurant offering various Asian cuisines. From Tehri website, 'Hing Kee is a family-owned restaurant located in Chicago's Chinatown. Since 2007, we have been striving to bring Chicago the best handmade soup dumplings, traditional pulled noodles, and authentic Cantonese food.' From Titus Ruscitti's website, 'Hing Kee is located in the Square. They get your attention by putting the dumpling ladies in the front window. From there, they pretty much roll and fold dumplings all day. Lots of people like their Xiao Long Bao, aka soup dumplings, but they have other styles on offer. An order of potstickers from here will always come out nice and crisp. It's one of the better spots in Chinatown to enjoy dumplings.'

posts.name: Honey 1 BBQ
posts.note: Honey 1 BBQ is a family-run rib joint with a fiery secret sauce is a great budget-friendly option in Chicago’s Bucktown neighborhood. Chicagoan Jeff Mauro recommends the Mini Tips Combo: hunks of smoky meat served atop a mountain of fries and bathed in the restaurant's signature sauce. Honey 1 BBQ serves hickory-smoked BBQ classic's and BYOB (Bring your own beer) in a casual, counter-serve storefront with wood tables. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Barbecue enthusiasts adore the outstanding smoked meats coming out of this celebrated Bronzeville joint. Owner Robert Adams Sr. and his family cook tender ribs, rib tips, and hot links over wood fire in an aquarium-style glass smoker. They also offer other items like wings, fried fish, brisket, and pulled pork.'

posts.name: Honey Butter Fried Chicken
posts.note: Honey Butter Fried Chicken is a quick-serve outfit furnishes fried poultry, craft beer, and cocktails in rustic digs with a patio. From their website, 'Many years ago, one of the side dishes served during SDC Fried Chicken Dinner was griddled corn cakes with honey butter. Hastily plated portions of the chicken and side were piled high on small plates to be eaten by staff while standing in the kitchen. Somehow, the honey butter melted on the fried chicken. Mind-exploding discovery moment: honey butter is really delicious on fried chicken.' From the Chicago Eater website,'It may not serve your momma’s fried chicken — with bones, skin, et al. — but Honey Butter Fried Chicken makes swaths of Chicagoans feel like kids again when they dip their birds in that addictive honey butter. Since expanding from supper club to Avondale brick-and-mortar in fall 2013, lines form during peak lunch and dinner hours but move quickly at the cozy counter-service space.'

posts.name: House of Bing
posts.note: House of Bing serves common Chinese appetizers and entrees, including daily lunch specials, prepped in a plain storefront. From their website, 'House of Bing Chinese Cuisine and Lounge (formally known as House of Ing in Hyde Park) is the go-to place for Chinese food lovers in South Shore. Dine-in to experience our delectable menu, or take it to go.'

posts.name: Jim's Original
posts.note: Jim's Original is an old-school 24/7 hot dog stand (started in 1939) boasting the original Maxwell Street Polish sausage. You need to order a pork chop sandwich too. From their website, 'Jim's Original is the longest continuously operating hot dog stand to have once done business on Maxwell Street. Except for a short closure in 2001 when we were relocated from Maxwell Street to Union Avenue, we have been in business since 1939, with 62 years of history on Maxwell Street. Jim's was so well-known and has so consistently served Chicagoans that we became the cornerstone of the Old Maxwell Street Market until its relocation in 1994. People still identify the Old Maxwell Street Market with the sweet smell of onions that emanated from Jim's stand.'

posts.name: Jimmy's Red Hots
posts.note: Jimmy's Red Hots is a counter-serve stand slinging hot dogs, Polish sausages, fries, and tamales for over 55 years. From their website, 'No Ketchup Since 1954. Our founder, the original Jimmy understood great taste and quality ingredients. That is why he instilled in us that you never put ketchup on a Chicago-style hot dog. Jimmy’s is consistently voted top dog in local and national polls. Jimmy’s continues to be family owned and operated. For over 65 years, we’ve tried our best to keep serving what Chicago knows to be the best Depression style hot dogs and polish sausage. We do it our way or no way. What you see is what you get. You get what you pay for. No charge for the entertainment.'

posts.name: Johnnie's Beef
posts.note: Johnnie's Beef is a tiny, no-frills, cash-only hot dog stand serving sausage and beef along with Italian ice, fries, and shakes. From the Chicago Tribune 'On the beef sandwich familiarity scale, Italian beef resides beneath the French dip/pastrami/Philly cheesesteak top tier, on the next level down with the Buffalo beef on weck and Baltimore pit beef. From the Chicago Eater website, 'The best example of Chicago’s iconic Italian beef sandwiches exists outside of the city at the two suburban locations of Johnnie’s Beef. The original space in Elmwood Park is a relic that first opened in 1961 (there’s also a second location in Arlington Heights). The menu is simple: beefs (the monosyllabic term locals use for Italian beef sandwiches), charcoal-grilled Italian sausages, and hot dogs. The thin-cut beef is moist and perfectly seasoned with hints of oregano. The hot peppers deliver plenty of heat but don’t overwhelm the meat. Don’t sleep on the beef-sausage sandwich, which combines tender slices of Italian beef with a robust sausage. Pepper-and-egg sandwiches are also available daily; they’re mostly aimed at Catholic customers who need a meat-free option on Lent Fridays. For dessert, there’s a stellar lemon Italian ice. While the city has plenty of beef options, Johnnie’s is worth the drive to the ‘burbs.''

posts.name: J.P. Graziano Grocery
posts.note: J.P. Graziano Grocery is a long-running Italian market and sandwich shop offering subs and specialty food items since 1937. From their website, 'We are a fourth-generation family-owned and operated Italian grocery store. Located in Chicago’s West Loop, we are the grocery shop with the most established presence and a reputation you can count on. People come for subs, for antipasti trays, for our desserts, and to buy authentic Chicago-style Italian foods for their own pantry. Known locally for our imported Italian delicacies, we’re also a popular choice for lunch for those who are nearby. Some will even come out of their way, craving the taste of our food.'

posts.name: Kuma's Corner
posts.note: Kuma's Corner is a busy, hopping pub known for its long list of creative burgers and its rock 'n' roll soundtrack. I have heard you need to order one of their burgers. From their website, 'Kuma’s started in 2005 with its flagship location at the corner of Belmont and Francisco avenues in Chicago’s Avondale neighborhood. From our origins as a corner bar with solid American bistro fare, we’ve grown to six locations that offer the finest burgers available on this planet or any other. Our ethos is simple. Support your community. Eat beef. Bang your head. We’re a gourmet burger bar that name all of our menu items after heavy metal bands.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Lonesome Rose
posts.note: Lonesome Rose serves creative Mexican and Tex-Mex fare and craft cocktails in a stylized warehouse setting with two bars. Titus Ruscitti recommends the tater tots, pork adobada, cheese, crema, pico, and jalapeño. It's a mess of a brunch for a mess of a snow day. From the Chicago Eater website, 'At night, this spot from the same crew behind tiki wonderland Lost Lake becomes a taco haven for Logan Square-ites with margaritas and excellent cocktails abound. During the day, breakfast tacos, coffee, and plenty of windows make this place just right for settling in.'

posts.name: Ludlow Liquors
posts.note: Ludlow Liquors is a funky spot for craft cocktails by the ounce paired with creative bar food in a retro-chic setting. The Chicago Magazine recommends ordering the Ratty Patty. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Square-cut pizza is only available for carryout for Ludlow Liquors in Avondale. Slices including a Philly roast pork, pepperoni, and two meat-free options, Also, there’s ranch dressing involved. That will either be salvation or Armageddon for pizza fans.'

posts.name: Manny's Coffee Shop and Deli
posts.note: Manny's Coffee Shop and Deli is a storied, no-frills institution serving classic deli fare in a cafeteria-style setting. From their website, 'It is our home away from home. As you walk through our doors, know that we welcome you to our home. Our food and recipes have been handed down from generation to generation. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Manny's Cafeteria and Deli is the epitome of a Chicago classic, serving outstanding corned beef and pastrami sandwiches, potato latkes, and other Jewish deli favorites to an eclectic crowd. It’s also a favorite of local politicians for power breakfasts.'

posts.name: Mercat a la Planxa
posts.note: Mercat a la Planxa serves a creative Catalan-inspired tapas and inventive cocktails in a swanky setting overlooking Grant Park. My friend recommends the tasing menu and drink pairing. From their website, 'Mercat’s ambitious menu captivates diners with its masterful remix of authentic Spanish cuisine with an emphasis in the Catalonian region. From street food-styled starters to meal-sized classics, rice, and grilled specialties from our planxa grill, each dish leads diners to another stage along Mercat’s culinary adventure. Complementing the rich cultural experience is an extensive, yet finely curated selection of cava, sangria, wine, and cocktail creations.'

posts.name: mfk. restaurant
posts.note: mfk. restaurant is a seafood-focused eatery for rare and global fish dishes in a cozy, seaside-inspired space with a bar. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Hidden below ground level, this intimate Spanish restaurant in Lakeview captures the essence of seaside eating through coastal delights like crunchy prawn heads, boquerones, seafood fideos, and Basque cake.'

posts.name: Mr. Beef
posts.note: Mr. Beef is a no-frills spot supplying classic Chicago eats like Italian beef that appeals to late-night diners.You need to order the Italian Beef sandwich and the Chicago Dog with everything. From the Chicago Eater website, 'There are dining options aplenty in River North but few are as satisfying as this old-school spot. The nostalgia-laden space — complete with celebrity photos lining the walls — stands in stark contrast to the rest of the neighborhood, while the beef sits in a jus bath to enhance the flavor before being loaded onto a crusty roll that’s able to hold up to the juices.'

posts.name: Mr. Dumpling
posts.note: From the Mr. Dumpling website, 'Mr. Dumpling is a new dumpling restaurant in Lincoln Park. We feature quality ingredients and great service for our Dumpling Cuisine. We've been dedicated to offering the most memorable dining experience for you. We pick ingredients carefully and use only the freshest and natural ones to prepare every dish, and have been trying to cook them in a healthier way to provide the most nutritious food. Much attention has been attached to ensure you a cozy and inviting ambiance where you could enjoy not only the great meal but also the authentic atmosphere.' From Titus Ruscitti's website, 'Lincoln Park continues to be a spot that sees some interesting Chinese restaurant openings. One of the more recent is Mr. Dumpling on Clark. While the menu boasts a selection of both traditional and American Chinese entrees, the namesake dumplings are what brought me in. They offer a nice selection of fillings, and you can try them steamed or pan-fried. They're on the smaller side, being two bites at most.'

posts.name: Monteverde Restaurant and Pastificio
posts.note: Monteverde Restaurant and Pastificio is a stylish spot serving refined, contemporary Italian fare such as fresh pasta's, along with global wines. Phil from the show Somebody Feed Phil (Netflix) recommends ordering the pork and ricotta ravioli or the Tigelle with prosciutto butter or the pasta with sauce pork Sopressata meatballs, pork sausage, pork shank, and a little salad. From the Chicago Eater website, 'The first restaurant from former Top Chef and Spiaggia chef Sarah Grueneberg has quickly cemented itself as one of Chicago’s top Italian destinations and its tough-to-get reservations are a prime example. The pastas are the stars at the West Loop hotspot, such as cannelloni saltimbocca with merguez lamb sausage, manchego cheese, peas, harissa, and balsamico, many of which are made on a small demonstration stage of sorts behind the bar. Also try non-pasta dishes such as the skate wing schnitzel and ‘nduja arancini, as well as a standout wine list.'

posts.name: New York Bagel and Bialy
posts.note: New York Bagel and Bialy is a 24-hour strip-mall shop that serves up bagels, bialys, and deli sandwiches at the counter in a snug space. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Located in a low-key suburban strip mall, New York Bagel and Bialy Corporation has helped keep Midwest-based bagel enthusiasts sane with its freshly baked wares since 1965. Mornings call for the “New York Breakfast,” or sausage, egg, and cheese on a bagel or bialy.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Old Town Ale House
posts.note: Old Town Ale House is laid-back, a cash-only dive bar near Second City with a storied past, old-school jukebox and funky art. From the Chicago Eater website, 'The Old Town Ale House is a slice of Chicago history. They don’t make dives like this anymore. A staple in Old Town since the 1950s since the neighborhood was a bohemian hangout, the bar features portrait of the regulars on the walls, all painted by owner Bruce Elliot, and a lending library for bookworms.

posts.name: Old Fashioned Donuts
posts.note: Old Fashioned Donuts is located on a sleepy stretch of Michigan Avenue (yes, THAT Michigan Avenue) since 1972. They have been serving the far South Side neighborhood of Roseland for 41 years. Owner Buritt Bulloch works on display in the front window, a rhythmic concentration on his kindly face and a gloving of flour on his well-worn hands. Regulars queue up in the sunlit foyer, patiently waiting their turn with the owner's daughter behind the counter. Some know exactly what they want, while others are treated to a matter-of-fact recitation of the shop's expansive options. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Go big or go home at the legendary Old Fashioned Donuts. The Texas doughnuts are large enough to fit around an arm while fruit-studded apple fritters are just as hearty, so bring an appetite or several companions. Owner Buritt Bulloch, now in his 80s, opened the shop with his late wife Mamie in 1972.' NOTE: Cash only.

posts.name: Pequod's Pizza
posts.note: Pequod's Pizza is a casual, brick-walled pizza pub where deep-dish pies with caramelized crusts are served until late. Phil from Somebody Feed Phil (Netflix) recommends ordering the deep dish pizza, which can be customized. From their website,' The year was 1970. Hidden away on Fernald Avenue in Morton Grove, Illinois, Pequods Pizza started a cult following for its pan-style pizza with a “caramelized crust” edge. Mozzarella cheese is cooked along the edge of a cast-iron pan creating a crust unlike any other. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Locals haven’t experienced deep dish nirvana until they've tried caramelized crust. At Pequod, order pies loaded with sausage, spinach, ground beef, giardiniera, and more and see how a burnt, cheesy crust can drastically enhance an already-great classic. The original location is in Morton Grove.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Portillo's Hot Dogs
posts.note: From their website, ‘We’re known for our famous Chicago-style hot dogs, Italian beef sandwiches, chopped salad, cheese fries, homemade chocolate cake, and chocolate cake shake. Our Italian beef is slow-roasted for four hours, thinly sliced, and served on freshly baked French bread. Then, it’s dipped in hot gravy made with our homemade blend of seasonings that we’ve been perfecting for 50 years. Haven’t tried Portillo’s yet? Order an Italian beef dipped with sweet or hot peppers (add mozzarella if you’re feeling cheesy), or a Chicago-style hot dog “dragged through the garden,” and you’ll see what all the hype is about.’ From the Chicago Eater website, ‘It’s true: Chicago’s beloved fast-food chain makes a mean sandwich that manages to hold its own against the city’s dedicated Italian beef purveyors. The menu also offers a non-traditional choice, the “Beef-N-Cheddar Croissant,” as well as a “Big Beef” for the biggest appetites. And thanks to several dozen locations across Chicagoland, a quality Italian beef is never too far away.’ Joshua recommends ordering the Italian Beef sandwich. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Potsticker House
posts.note: Ed's Pot Sticker House is a no-frills Chinese-food specialist serving dumplings and traditional fare along with less familiar dishes. From Titus Ruscitti's website, 'Ed's makes cigar-style potstickers, and for that reason alone, they're worth visiting. These dumplings are long and thin and come filled with a traditional pork and chive filling.' From the Chicago Eater website, 'The restaurant formerly known as Ed's Pot Sticker House would be at home in the heart of Chinatown, with the Lazy Susans and Northern Chinese cuisine. Though they're known for their cigar-shaped potstickers, don't sleep on the crisp sweet-glazed eggplant or the cumin-flavor lamb with bone. But seriously, try that eggplant.'

posts.name: The Publican
posts.note: The Publican is a creative seafood and pork-focused menu plus global brews in a hip setting with communal tables. From the Chicago Eater website, 'It’s not just pork and seafood at one of Chicago’s most essential spots. The celebrated farm-to-table restaurant from One Off Hospitality Group serves a succulent plate of chicken using birds from Slagel Family Farm. It’s served with summer sausage and fries for a simple down-home meal.'

posts.name: Publican Quality Meats
posts.note: Publican Quality Meats is an American cafe offering charcuterie, pastries, and sandwiches along with an on-site butcher and market. From their website, 'Stop in and browse our butcher case that features in-house produced sausages and charcuterie, along with select meats from Slagel Family Farms. Our café sandwiches, salads, and soups are available daily from 10:30 AM - 3:00 PM.'

posts.name: Qing Xiang Yuan Dumplings
posts.note: Qing Xiang Yuan Dumplings is a minimalist, BYOB nook with an open kitchen preparing artisanal Chinese dumplings with many fillings. Titus Ruscitti recommends the classic of pork and cabbage the most as far as potsticker fillings go but don't forget about the lamb or beef ones. From the Chicago Eater Website, 'Arguably the finest dumplings in Chicago can be had in Chinatown. Qing Xiang Yuan Dumplings specializes in soup dumplings filled with everything from pork and lamb to premium ingredients like lobster and sea urchin. Barbecue skewers are popular as well.'

posts.name: Quartino Ristorante
posts.note: From the Quartino Ristorante website, 'Quartino is a bustling downtown Chicago restaurant, and wine bar noted for its distinctive Italian small- plates menu, vintage decor, and attentive, personable service staff. Our menu features Italy’s regional specialties, including artisanal salumi, Neapolitan thin-crust pizza, house-made pasta, and seasonal dishes. Menu items, served in moderate portions and meant to be shared, are perfect for adventurous diners ready for a unique experience.' From the Chicago Eater website, 'Like a good nonna, this bustling River North eatery delivers consistently reliable Italian fare. Enlist some dining companions, order a bottle of wine, and nosh on housemade salumi, Neapolitan pizzas, and shareable small plates. Locals and tourists might not have much common ground, but they can all agree that Quartino’s veal meatballs and soft, pillowy gnocchi are delicious.'

posts.name: Ramen Wasabi
posts.note: From the Ramen Wasabi website, 'Established in 2010, Wasabi has been the “secret gem” among the local and non-local customers in Chicago's new destination spot. Wasabi is one of few Japanese owned Japanese restaurants in Chicago that offers a full range of both traditional and contemporary Japanese cuisine to bring an unique Japanese dining experience. Wasabi is everything you'd expect and nothing you'd imagine: Small plates (Izakaya-style) and an authentic Japanese ramen made from boiling pork bones for days. At Wasabi, we use the freshest and high-quality ingredients.' From the Chicago Eater website, 'Ramen is a labor of love, and at Ramen Wasabi, it shows. Though the menu offers a selection of Asian small plates, ramen is the main attraction. Rich and creamy tonkotsu broth is slow-cooked for days and served with Berkshire pork belly, soft-boiled egg, bamboo shoots, scallions, sesame, wood ear mushrooms, and garlic oil. To dial up the heat, opt for the spicy roasted garlic miso ramen loaded with chili peppers.'

posts.name: Rex Italian Foods, Inc
posts.note: Rex Italian Foods, Inc is a counter-serve Italian store that serves entrees, and sandwiches served at a small sit-down section inside a food market. Get their pressed ham, peppers, and cheese sandwich. From tehir website, 'The family at Rex Italian Foods, Inc. would like to be a part of your family’s next occasion. Whether it’s a small business lunch or a big graduation party, we have all your catering needs. Besides our catering, we’d like to invite you to our storefront for a wide variety of homemade Italian beef and sausage, homemade prepared entrées, imported Italian specialties, homemade pasta, imported and domestic items, lunchmeats, homemade cookies, and pastries.'

posts.name: RPM Steak
posts.note: RPM Steak is a chophouse with a modern menu of prime cuts, raw-bar items and more in a sleek setting with banquettes. I hear you need to order the beef cheeseburger and the lamb burger with middle eastern spices. From their website, 'Located in Chicago’s River North neighborhood, RPM Steak is an updated take on the classic steakhouse and features nearly two dozen different cuts of beef sourced from the finest butchers across the globe.'

posts.name: Sarkis Cafe
posts.note: Sarkis Cafe is a small mainstay draws crowds for its classic breakfast fare served in a diner-style environment. from their website, 'Sarkis Café has been an Evanston institution since 1965. It was established, by Sarkis Tashjian a larger than life personality. He used his Armenian roots and his personal flair to parlay breakfast food into a breakfast experience for the next 35 years. The restaurant was purchased by Jeff Cramin in 2000 and remains owned and operated by the Cramin family to this day. Our menu items are as unique as the café itself. Our signature sandwiches are unlike any other and have many interesting back stories.'

posts.name: Saucy Porka
posts.note: Saucy Porka is a modern fusion of Latin and Asian comfort foods from a buzzy spot with food-truck roots. Order their Asian Paella with two types of sausage and glazed pork or pork tacos or the Cubana or pazolli soup which has pork and hominy. From their website, 'Our recipes honor the memories from grandmothers, mothers, aunts, and other nurturing family who taught us that a recipe is nothing without the love and soul one puts into it. This menu pays homage to the home-style cooking of Latin American and Asian cultures. The menu is inspired by the flavors of our family roots; while reminiscent of “authentic” dishes, these recipes are uniquely Saucy Porka. Although pork is the starlet of the show, our menu also offers a variety of dishes that will satisfy non-pork, vegetarian, and vegan-seeking diners.'

posts.name: The Spice House
posts.note: The Spice House is a bright retail shop for all manner of rubs, salts, and extracts, plus made-in-house spice mixes. Alton Brown recommends ordering your spices from The Spice House, which I did. So no food here but great spice, salts, etc. to make wonderful things. From their website, 'Founded in 1957, The Spice House is a purveyor of the finest spices, herbs, blends, and extracts to customers ranging from renowned Michelin-star chefs to home cooks everywhere. We’ve spent over 60 years curating our global network of premium growers and distributors in order to offer our customers unrivaled quality and selection. Our products range from essential and rare spice varietals to proprietary rubs and blends.'

posts.name: Sun Wah BBQ
posts.note: Sun Wah BBQ is a long-running Chinese eatery known for its Hong Kong-style BBQ dishes, plus beer, and cocktails. It's a family-operated restaurant which has some of the best and most authentic Chinese barbecue in Chicago. Served up Hong Kong-style, menu highlights include peanut butter egg rolls, crispy Beijing duck and a whole roasted suckling pig that Rahm Fama says is 'mouthwateringly delicious.' You need to order the Whole Roasted Suckling Pig, Crispy Duck, the Roast Pork, or the Pork Chow Fun with rice noodles. From their website, 'Sun Wah BBQ started its journey in New York’s Chinatown where it was crammed into a storefront hardly wider than nine lengths of roast ducks. Its founder, Eric Cheng continually refined his skills as a Hong Kong style barbecue chef here. While Sun Wah did well, it was still a crowded fish yearning for larger oceans. Eric and wife Lynda took their four toddlers and Eric’s mother and made Chicago their destination.'

posts.name: Superdawg Drive-In
posts.note: From their website, ‘Throughout the years, small changes have been made to the menu, like the addition of the Whoopskidawg® in 1989 and the  Superchic™ in 1991. However, the Superdawg™ recipe, the original trademark figures (continuing to flirtatiously wink at each other), and the drive-in concept have not changed. Customers can still order from their car and have a carhop deliver their order on a tray. Maurie and Flaurie’s attention to quality products and service, preparing each customer’s meal to order, affirming the belief that the customer is  always right, and insisting that the customer should always be treated  as family continues today.’ From the Chicago Eater website, ‘Avatars of  Superdawg founders Maurie and Flaurie Berman stand guard over this venerable Chicago drive-in at the intersection of Devon, Nagle, and  Milwaukee; customers can spot those giant hot dog statues bearing the Bermans’ likenesses from blocks away. Superdawg is a throwback experience where customers park their cars and talk to staff through crackling speakers, and carhops bring out trays of food. Superdawg’s offering isn’t a traditional Chicago-style dog. Rather than a Vienna  Beef frank, Superdawg uses a thick, proprietary all-beef sausage that comes with mustard, pickled green tomato, and chopped Spanish onions. This is all cradled in a box of crinkle fries. There’s a second suburban location in Wheeling.’

posts.name: Sweet Maple Cafe
posts.note: Sweet Maple Cafe is a country-style comfort food including all-day breakfasts, and hearty lunches served in a homey space. From their website, 'We do things the old-fashioned way. Try our delectable homemade “sweet milk biscuits” or our “Not-So-Plain Buttermilk Pancakes,” served with pure Vermont maple syrup. And new dishes, like Dr. Glenn’s Scramble with farm-fresh scrambled eggs, chunks of succulent bone-in ham, Wisconsin cheddar, and sautéed vegetables, are not to be missed.' From the Chicago Eater website, 'Battle the throngs of college students and University Village locals to snag a table at this home-style cafe on Taylor Street. The rewards — hearty scrambles, customizable omelets, fluffy pancakes, home fries, and corned beef hash — are worth the effort.'

posts.name: Taipei Cafe
posts.note: Taipei Cafe is a relaxed, modern spot for Taiwanese fare, including hot pots, plus hot or cold tea drinks. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Beef noodle soup, a beloved dish in Taiwan and Southeast Asia, takes center stage at Bridgeport’s Taipei Cafe. The spicy beef broth is loaded with tender braised beef, chewy noodles, pickled cabbage, and green onion. Variations include an herbal broth version.' From Titus Ruscitti's website, 'Taipei Cafe sits in a strip mall on Halsted in Bridgeport. The neighborhood that's home to the White Sox is quickly becoming home to more and more Chinese restaurants up and down the block. As you might expect from the name, the food from Taiwan is on the feature here. There are some good dishes to be found up and down the menu, with the potstickers being one of them. They're stuffed with pork in a small rectangle shape before being cooked in a pan, which gives each order a half-circle of crispy lattice coating.'

posts.name: Taqueria Chingón
posts.note: From Chicago Eater website about Taqueria Chingón, 'Taqueria Chingón, the Mexico City-style taqueria from chefs Sotero Gallegos (Le Sardine), Marcos Ascencio (Bar Lupo, Nomi), and Oliver Poilevey of Le Bouchon, debuted Friday on Western Avenue to a long line of excited patrons, according to an Instagram post. The trio feature seven tacos, including crispy pig head carnitas (“Mexican giardiniera,” Arbol salsa), vegetarian al pastor (marinated portobello, celery root, pineapple), and Costilla (short rib, pea tendrils, hazelnuts). They’re also offering a Que Rico Chingón Special — al pastor meat available by the half or full pound — plus pozole, ceviche, and quesadillas.' Titus Ruscitti recommends the Morcilla (Blood Sausage, Pickled Apple, Red Onion, Salsa Macha), Al Pastor, Green Chorizo, and Carne Asada. Looking at the menu, I would like to try the Pig Head Carnitas, which is Crispy Pig Head, Mexican Giardiniera, and Arbol Salsa.

posts.name: Top Notch Beefburgers
posts.note: Top Notch Beefburgers is a South Side spot that has been serving burgers, beef-fat fries, and shakes since 1942. From the Chicago Eater website, 'A longstanding South Side institution that’s been around since 1942, Top-Notch Beefburgers is one of the last of a dwindling breed of classic Chicago grease joints and perhaps the best. The burgers, which come in three sizes, are made exclusively of meat from the cow leg and accompanied by cheese, lettuce, tomato, pickles, mayo, and raw or grilled onions.

posts.name: Torizen
posts.note: Torizen is a modest strip-mall eatery offering heaping bowls of ramen noodles plus other Japanese dishes. From their website, 'Established in November of 2017, Torizen is a “ramen/izakaya” style restaurant concentrating on traditional Japanese dishes and the only restaurant in Illinois, specializing in Sapporo-style ramen noodle soup. Owner/chef has had over 20 years experience as a chef, and will strive to create, serve the best Japanese food, Torizen has to offer.'

posts.name: Tortello
posts.note: Tortello serves housemade pasta and sauces from an open kitchen, served at a counter for casual dining or takeout. Jason Fried tweeted, 'Simple menu, seriously good pasta. Very legit. Dario, the owner, is running something special over there.' From their website, 'Born and raised in Italy, Dario Monni has been steeped in the rich food culture of Italy from an early age. In his hometown of Venice, Monni learned the art of preparing handmade pasta from his “nonna” while listening to stories of his grandfather’s specialty foods store. His summers were spent with relatives on his father’s side in rural Sardinia, where his family worked as shepherds, cheese-mongers, and butchers, imparting onto him the deep-rooted value of the region’s unique rituals, pristine ingredients and simple dedication to an authentic craft.

posts.name: Tortillería y Taquerías Atotonilco
posts.note: Tortillería y Taquerías Atotonilco is a local Mexican counter-serve chain offering breakfast, tacos, burritos and shakes in a low-key space. My buddy says the thing to order is the El Pastor and the skirt steak tacos with corn tortillas which were fantastic. NOTE: They have multiple locations with the original one located at 3916 W. 26th St., Chicago, IL 60623, and its phone number is 773-762-3380.

posts.name: urbanbelly
posts.note: The functional eatery urbanbelly is whipping up hearty Asian fusion grub in straightforward digs with communal tables. I heard the thing to order there are their dumplings. From the Chicago Eater website, 'Bill Kim’s fast-casual restaurant deploys a range Asian flavors in exciting ways. Noodles are a big part of the menu and the non-traditional ramen has been a longtime staple, featuring a pho-like soup base with braised pork belly, radish, mushrooms, and soft-boiled egg. Urbanbelly is open for indoor and outdoor dining, and takeout or delivery via third party services. Kim also has a ramen stall at the Time Out Chicago food hall in Fulton Market.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Valois Restaurant
posts.note: Valois Restaurant is a counter-service smorgasbord of American comfort food served in a casual, muraled space. From thier website, 'We take pride in serving large wholesome meals made from natural ingredients and served to the customer in a timely manner at a reasonable price. Valois is not your ordinary restaurant, but it’s an experience you must see to truly understand the Valois concept. We are located in the heart of Hyde Park by the University of Chicago.' From the Chicago EAter website, 'The gimmick at this Hyde Park landmark is the promise that customers can “see your food.” But for loyalists, Valois is no novelty: the cafeteria-style restaurant has been an essential part of the community since 1921. The items on the line rotate in and out throughout the day. Church groups assemble for breakfast and politicians make sure to be photographed here during election season. The restaurant has made loyal customers out of famous Chicagoans over the years, including former President Barack Obama and the late White Sox owner Bill Veeck.' NOTE: Cash only.

posts.name: Virtue Restaurant
posts.note: Virtue Restaurant serves hearty Southern cooking paired with wines and cocktails in funky-chic quarters with an open kitchen. Phil from Somebody Feed Phil (Netflix) recommends the Salmon and succotash with corn puree. From their website, 'Stationed in the Hyde Park neighborhood of Chicago, Virtue is a Southern American restaurant that leads with a culture of hospitality and kindness. We’ve worked hard to create a warm, honest, and thoughtful space. We pride ourselves on unpretentious service, timing, and, most importantly, providing great value. At Virtue, we use heritage techniques to create some familiar flavors and some new ones.'
